p: The NHP carcasses were collected in the field by health surveillance agents (Brazilian Yellow Fever Surveillance Program [ 16], frozen (-20 °C), and transported to the Laboratory of Zoonosis of Belo Horizonte/Minas Gerais (LZOON-BH). At LZOON-BH, NHP carcasses were defrosted and visually inspected regarding the stage of decomposition, taking into account different tissue aspects: ( i) brightness (bright or opaque); ( ii) color (regular aspect, greenish, greyish or whitish); ( iii) consistency (if the tissue was firm or softened); ( iv) smell (whether the carcass was smelling rotten or not); and ( v) presence or absence of parasites (larvae). Based on that, liver samples were categorized according to their preservation status: good (n = 465; 59.5%), intermediate (n = 211; 27.0%), or bad (n = 59; 7.5%). After defrosting, liver fragments (0.5 cm) were collected from the carcasses and placed into microtubes containing RNA later solution (Ambion, USA) by the LZOON team. The microtubes were kept at 4 °C for 16 hours and then stored at -20 °C until used for RNA extraction at Laboratório de Vírus/Universidade Federal de Minas Gerais (UFMG).
